thread.title: Brazil charges executives with corruption

title: Brazil charges executives with corruption
text:
Petrobras scandal ensnares power group 
The charges came as the judge overseeing the case, Sergio Moro, ordered the continued detention of Marcelo Odebrecht, the head of the conglomerate, who was arrested last month, after the court received new evidence from investigators in Switzerland. 
“According to the Swiss authorities and the documents presented, there is proof, in summary, of millions [of dollars] in fund flows, in tens of transactions, between accounts controlled by Odebrecht [the company] and funded by Odebrecht [the company] and secret accounts maintained abroad by Petrobras executives,” Judge Moro said in a court decision on Mr Odebrecht’s continued detention. 
The formal charging of an executive of the calibre of Marcelo Odebrecht, who once strode atop the corporate scene of Latin   almost unprecedented in Brazil. 
The investigation into Petrobras, in which prosecutors allege company officials collaborated with politicians and contractors to extract bribes from the company, has broken all previous boundaries in the prosecution of white-collar and political crimes in the country. 
Mr Odebrecht, who heads the unlisted family-run conglomerate, has vigorously denied the allegations against him. 
The company’s operations span roads, airports, dams and even a nuclear submarine base being built near the city of Rio de Janeiro. 
The parent company reported revenue of $10.2bn last year from 191 projects in 18 countries, with more than two-thirds of this coming from outside Brazil. 
The police also accuse Mr Odebrecht of attempting to manipulate the investigation, citing notes that he wrote to his lawyers. He has rejected the charges. FT View 
Recession and graft: the growing rot in Brazil 
Incompetence, arrogance and corruption have shattered Brazil’s magic spell. Combined with the end of the commodity boom, they have driven the world’s eighth biggest economy into a deepening recession. 
Continue reading 
Analysts believe, however, that the case against Odebrecht could be a stepping stone for a separate investigation against the former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva . 
Prosecutors accuse Mr Lula da Silva of illegal influence-peddling in his dealings with Odebrecht, saying he helped the company win overseas contracts with the promise of backing from the state-owned development bank, BNDES. 
Analysts say prosecutors will be hoping that Odebrecht executives might enter into plea bargains and testify against the former president in exchange for leniency. 
“We still view the [allegations] against Lula as difficult to prove. The real liability is if the Odebrecht executives currently in prison . . . including the company’s president Marcelo Odebrecht, choose to co-operate with authorities,” said Joao Augusto de Castro Neves of Eurasia Group in a note. 
“Notably, Alexandrino Alencar, Odebrecht’s head of institutional relations, is one of those imprisoned, and was the person that accompanied the former president on the trips in question.” 
Mr Lula da Silva has denied any wrongdoing.
